did.unittitle: Union League of Philadelphia historical papers

bioghist.p: The Union League of Philadelphia was founded in 1862 as a patriotic society to support the policies of President Abraham Lincoln. It evolved to its current identity as a non-sectarian and non-partisan private club. Ferdinand J. Dreer evidently collected photographs and autographs of Union Club members, and saved Union Club meeting invitations and other memorabilia relating to the early years of the Club. This material has been supplemented by additions from Boker's invitations to the Club's annual dinners and other memorabilia together with some later additions. The Military Committee of the Union League raised nine regiments of infantry, five cavalry companies, and five regiments of U.S. Colored Troops. From 1863 to 1865 the Union League sent Silver Medals in appreciation of distinguished services and conferring privileges of membership.

scopecontent.p: The series is arranged into two subseries: Union Club/Dreer Collection; and Union League and the Civil War. The Dreer Collection includes Union Club weekly meeting invitations to Dreer, 1863-1865; responses to Dreer's Club party, February, 1863, from every (or nearly) member; annual dinner notices, with some correspondence and bills addressed to Boker and Clarence H. Clark, 1866-1906; Union Club minutebook, 1865-1906; and alphabetical biographical file various Club members, mostly obituaries. The Civil War material includes: broadsides, clippings, correspondence (with Boker) and other ephemera, 1861-1903; Military Committee proceedings, correspondence, bounties, and other miscellaneous military, 1862-1867; and acknowledgments of receipt of silver medal, 1863-1865.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
